ygData.subject: Re: How to add objects

--- In gladiator@y..., "dph_of_rules" <dph_of_rules@u...> wrote:
> Note: I am going to add my comments in a reply, since I have had 
> trouble getting this message sent.

I had trouble getting this message posted twice.  I'm a little annoyed 
about that.  If some of my comments seem short, it's because I have 
typed this message twice before.

Here's my general comments:
1)Never attempt to add, delete, or modify objects by code to your 
original file.  It's too damn easy to screw the file up.
2)Read comment 1 again.
3)Always keep track of what byte number you are on when adding or 
deleting objects by code.
4)Read comment 3 again.  When I first attempted to delete files, I 
forgot to do this and ended up screwing a file up.
5)Always keep track of variable types when adding or modifying objects 
by code.  If the information you read was one type of variable, then 
when you put into that same information into a new file, it should be 
the exact same variable type.
6)Read comment 5 again.  I forgot to do this when adding objects and 
got extremely frustrated trying to find the problem in my code.
7)read these comments again before proceeding.
 

**Comments about 1st section of code

intCounter is used to keep track of the byte number in the original 
file.  intCount3 is used to keep track of the byte number in the new 
file.  Everything else I have posted before.

**end comments about 2nd section of code
 
 **2nd section of code**
 ReDim strucThings(1 To Filestruc.intObjectCount) As Objectstruct
 intCounter = 48
 intCount3 = intCounter
 'we are going to start adding some exits to the next scenario here
 For intY = 1328 To 1360 Step 16
 'I want the height to be 16 units apart
     For intX = 896 To 1072 Step 176
         'I want two columns
         Put #2, intCount3, CByte(2)
         'setting the order number as byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 1, CByte(8)
         'setting the family number as byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 2, CInt(intX)
         'setting the X position as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 4, CInt(intY)
         'setting the Y position as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 6, CByte(0)
         'setting the team number as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 7, CByte(0)
         'setting the facing value as a byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 8, CByte(2)
         'setting the command value as a byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 9, CInt(165)
         'setting the level value as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 11, ""
         'setting the objects name
         Put #2, intCount3 + 23, "MSTRMSTRMS"
         'setting the reserved value
         Filestruc.intObjectCount = Filestruc.intObjectCount + 1
         'increasing the object count
         Put #2, 46, Filestruc.intObjectCount
         'updating the object count to our new file
         intCount3 = intCount3 + 33
         'resetting the location on our new file
         intCount4 = intCount4 + 1
     Next intX
 Next intY
 
 intY = 1376
 For intX = 896 To 1072 Step 16
 'I want these 16 units apart
     Put #2, intCount3, CByte(2)
     'setting the order number as byte
     Put #2, intCount3 + 1, CByte(8)
     'setting the family number as byte
     Put #2, intCount3 + 2, CInt(intX)
     'setting the X position as an integer
     Put #2, intCount3 + 4, CInt(intY)
     'setting the Y position as an integer
     Put #2, intCount3 + 6, CByte(0)
     'setting the team number as an integer
     Put #2, intCount3 + 7, CByte(0)
     'setting the facing value as a byte
     Put #2, intCount3 + 8, CByte(2)
     'setting the command value as a byte
     Put #2, intCount3 + 9, CInt(163)
     'setting the level value as an integer
     Put #2, intCount3 + 11, ""
     'setting the objects name
     Put #2, intCount3 + 23, "MSTRMSTRMS"
     'setting the reserved value
     Filestruc.intObjectCount = Filestruc.intObjectCount + 1
     'increasing the object count
     Put #2, 46, Filestruc.intObjectCount
     'updating the object count to our new file
     intCount3 = intCount3 + 33
     'resetting the location on our new file
      intCount4 = intCount4 + 1
      'keeping track of the number of objects added
 Next intX
**end 2nd section of code**

CByte() coerces [I love the way Visual Basic documentation expresses 
this] a number into becoming a byte type variable.  CInt() coerces a 
number into becoming a integer type variable.  You do need to keep 
track of the objects you have added.  I prefer, when only adding 
objects, to update the number of objects in the new file every time I 
add an object. [You do not have to update the number of objects now, 
but sooner or later you will have to.]  Because I updated that count, 
I'll have to preform a calculation to determine the number of objects 
in the old file or read that information again.
 
**Comments about 3rd section**

You've seen all of this before, except for the calculation, which is 
explained in the built-in remarks.

**end comments about 3rd section**
 
 **4th section of code**
     If ((strucThings(intCount).bitOrder = 5) And 
 (strucThings(intCount).bitFamily = 0)) Then
     'I am placing exits to the previous scenario next to initial 
 player positions
         Put #2, intCount3, CByte(2)
         'setting the order number as byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 1, CByte(8)
         'setting the family number as byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 2, CInt(strucThings(intCount).intXpos - 
 16)
         'setting the X position as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 4, CInt(strucThings(intCount).intYpos + 
 16)
         'setting the Y position as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 6, CByte(0)
         'setting the team number as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 7, CByte(0)
         'setting the facing value as a byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 8, CByte(2)
         'setting the command value as a byte
         Put #2, intCount3 + 9, CInt(163)
         'setting the level value as an integer
         Put #2, intCount3 + 11, ""
         'setting the objects name
         Put #2, intCount3 + 23, "MSTRMSTRMS"
         'setting the reserved value
         Filestruc.intObjectCount = Filestruc.intObjectCount + 1
         'increasing the object count
         Put #2, 46, Filestruc.intObjectCount
         'updating the object count to our new file
         intCount3 = intCount3 + 33
         'resetting the location on our new file
         intCount4 = intCount4 + 1
         'keeping track of the number of objects added
     End If
    
 Next intCount
**end 4th section of code**

Yep, I'm adding objects again.  If by now, you haven't updated the 
number of objects in the new file, it would be a good idea to do so 
now BEFORE proceeding to handle the text.  Yes, I don't have to keep 
track of the number of new objects at this point, but I do prefer to 
in case I ran into problems.
 
**comments about 5th section of code**

You've all seen it before.  Nothing new.

**end comments about 5th section of code**

If there any questions about the code, email the questions.

I am NOT posting code to attempt to convince people I am an expert 
programmer [If you believe this, will you give me your email so that I 
can add you as a reference so that I can update my resume so that I 
can get a job as a computer programmer?].  I am posting code to remove 
the mystery of how to do things to a scenario file by code.

Yes, the code I have posted was used to help me fix my scenarios.  I 
have one left that I plan on working on.  I going to post to code to 
solve that problem because it involves adding, deleting, and modifying 
objects all at once.  Once I finish that, I'll start working on 
writing code to sort objects (I hope I can remember how to sort 
efficiently.).  Meanwhile at that point, I'll be working on my own 
scenario converter/editor implementing the cool features of adding, 
modifying, and deleting objects wide-scale.
